channel.title: NYT > Business
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trump Wants to Revive Shipping. Investors Are Slow to Back Him.
item.description: A French logistics behemoth promised $20 billion for the United States, but a year into President Trump’s second term, only a fraction of the money has arrived.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Maansi Srivastava for The New York Times
item.media:description: “He’s going to be investing $20 billion into the United States because of the election,” President Trump said last year when Rodolphe Saadé, the chief executive of the shipping company CMA CGM, visited the White House.

item.title: F.D.A. Refuses to Review Moderna Flu Vaccine
item.description: The vaccine maker’s shots involve the successful Covid vaccines’ RNA technology. Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has broadly rejected it, canceling millions of dollars in research projects.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett and Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: Moderna is a pioneer in using mRNA technology, first with the Covid vaccine. Its flu shot was being developed for people 50 and older.

item.title: Ford Says Electric Vehicle Losses Will Continue for 3 More Years
item.description: Ford Motor reported a big loss for 2025 because of its troubled electric vehicle division, which it has significantly scaled back.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:credit: Brett Carlsen for The New York Times
item.media:description: An F-150 Lightning electric pickup truck, which the company stopped producing last year, after federal tax credits for electric vehicles ended.

item.title: Epstein Files Reveal Efforts to Build Ties With Russian Officials, Including Putin
item.description: New documents detail Jeffrey Epstein’s efforts to foster strategic, sometimes reciprocal relationships with Russian officials.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Nataliya Vasilyeva
item.media:description: The latest released files show that Jeffrey Epstein had hoped to facilitate a meeting with the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin.

item.title: NLRB Dismisses Case Brought by Fired SpaceX Employees
item.description: The National Labor Relations Board, having accused the company of unfair retaliation in 2024, now says it has no jurisdiction over Elon Musk’s space company.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber and Ryan Mac
item.media:description: Eight SpaceX employees were fired soon after asking the company to distance itself from comments made by Elon Musk, including one in which he made light of accusations of harassment directed at him.

item.title: The Whiskey World Is Reeling, but Uncle Nearest Has Bigger Troubles
item.description: A new report paints a grim financial picture of Uncle Nearest, a high-profile brand named for an enslaved distiller. But its founder disputes the findings.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Laura Partain for The New York Times

item.title: Ahead of Jobs Report, White House Seeks to Downplay Any Slowdown
item.description: President Trump’s top aides have argued in recent days that the economy is strong, even if new data on Wednesday show sluggish hiring.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: For the president, a dour jobs report could prove politically noxious.

item.title: Epstein Directed Aide to Obtain Hidden Video Cameras
item.description: “I’m installing them into Kleenex boxes now,” the aide replied in the 2014 email exchange.
item.dc:creator: David Enrich and Debra Kamin

item.title: Lutnick, Wasserman and Others Caught Up in Epstein Files
item.description: Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick and Casey Wasserman, the entertainment mogul, are among those facing blowback amid the release of files related to Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly and Brian O’Keefe
item.media:description: Representatives Ro Khanna, Democrat of California, and Thomas Massie, Republican of Kentucky, are part of a bipartisan political push to shed more light on the Jeffrey Epstein ordeal.

item.title: BP Suspends Share Buybacks as Profit Slumps
item.description: The British energy giant said it would put money toward new oil and gas opportunities ahead of the arrival of its new chief executive, Meg O’Neill.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:description: BP is turning back to its traditional oil and gas business in an effort to revive its fortunes.

item.title: Operator of Eddie Bauer Stores Files for Bankruptcy
item.description: The company that operates the brand’s retail stores cited a shift in consumer preferences, rising inflation and elevated tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Laura Chung
item.media:credit: Andrew Spear for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eddie Bauer’s retail operator has said it would seek to sell 180 stores across the United States and Canada.

item.title: Watch: A Conversation With Anna Wintour and Her U.S. Vogue Successor, Chloe Malle
item.description: In their first joint interview, Ms. Malle spoke about filling the shoes of Ms. Wintour, who urged people to “get over comparisons.”
item.dc:creator: Jessica Testa, Chevaz Clarke, Daniel Fetherston and Lauren Pruitt

item.title: Pilots and Flight Attendants Criticize American Airlines’ Performance
item.description: The unions representing pilots and flight attendants have in recent days publicly criticized American for falling behind Delta Air Lines and United Airlines.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:description: American Airlines had lost substantial ground to Delta Air Lines and United Airlines in recent years.

item.title: Court TV, Known for Live Trial Coverage, Is Getting a New Owner
item.description: E.W. Scripps is selling the channel to the parent company of Law&Crime, which wants Court TV to have a bigger streaming presence.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: James Jackman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Court TV booth at CrimeCon, an annual true-crime convention.

item.title: This Year’s Super Bowl Ads Were Dominated by AI Companies
item.description: Ads pitching artificial intelligence companies dominated the Super Bowl broadcast. Their huge cost probably didn’t ease investor worries about spending.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Ian Mount, Grady McGregor and Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
item.media:description: The large number of A.I. ads featured during the Super Bowl LX broadcast may go down as more memorable than the game itself.

item.title: Hollywood Braces for New Round of Labor Talks
item.description: The last time writers and actors negotiated contracts, in 2023, dual strikes froze the industry.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin
item.category: Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The SAG-AFTRA and Writers Guild strikes in 2023 brought production in Hollywood to a halt.

item.title: From Fishing Nets to Furniture: Turning Ocean Plastic Into Usable Products
item.description: A brother-and-sister team in Spain started a sustainable business model recycling old and damaged nets into stadium seating and decorations.
item.dc:creator: Lena Mucha For The New York Times

item.title: Japan Stocks Surge on Takaichi’s Landslide Election Win
item.description: Stocks climbed on Monday as investors cheered a result seen as a mandate for the prime minister’s high-spending economic agenda.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis
item.media:description: Sanae Takaichi is broadly viewed as a boon for corporate Japan because of her support for low interest rates and robust fiscal spending to stimulate growth.

item.title: Why the N.F.L. Booked Bad Bunny for the Super Bowl Halftime Show
item.description: League executives may be nervous about the Latin superstar’s outspoken stance on immigration, but their priority is attracting popular halftime performers.
item.dc:creator: Ken Belson
item.media:description: Bad Bunny performing in Mexico City in December. The choice of Bad Bunny as the Super Bowl halftime performer was, from a musical standpoint, an obvious one.

item.title: MAGA’s Split Over Israel Extends to a Ship Attacked 58 Years Ago
item.description: The Israeli military killed 34 people on the U.S.S. Liberty in 1967. Whether it was an accident, as many historians believe, has become a litmus test within President Trump’s movement.
item.dc:creator: Ken Bensinger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Israeli jets and torpedo boats attacked the Liberty, a U.S. Navy intelligence-gathering ship, near Sinai during the Six-Day War.

item.title: Two Volleyball Leagues Want to Be the Next W.N.B.A. Only One Can Win.
item.description: The race to create the next major women’s sport.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Weisberg and Daniel Guillemette
item.media:credit: Roger Kisby for The New York Times

item.title: Can AI Chatbots Write Emotionally Rich Romance Books?
item.description: The romance industry, always at the vanguard of technological change, is rapidly adapting to A.I. Not everyone is on board.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Charlotte Coppin for The New York Times
item.media:description: The author Coral Hart has become an evangelist for A.I.

item.title: Feeling ‘Amateur’ at Retirement Planning, They Asked A.I. for Help
item.description: More people are turning to chatbots for advice, inquiring about high-stakes decisions such as saving for retirement — even if they eventually turn to a human.
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Caitlyn Yingling used ChatGPT to help guide significant changes to her and her husband’s retirement accounts.

item.title: What to Know About Japan’s Economy on Election Day
item.description: Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi pushed through a record supplemental budget and is proposing tax cuts, raising questions about how the government will pay for it all.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis
item.media:description: A wholesale food market in Sapporo, Japan, in December. The facility is a hub for Japan’s trade, which was disrupted by a geopolitical dispute with China.

item.title: Hims & Hers Withdraws Knockoff Weight-Loss Pill After Regulatory Scrutiny
item.description: Federal officials had warned that the new product from the online provider of weight loss drugs might be illegal.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins

item.title: A Super Bowl in Silicon Valley Filled With Valley Billionaires
item.description: A who’s who of celebrities will join them. Just a little over 25 percent of the seats for the game will be for regular fans, with the cheapest ticket now selling for more than $4,000.
item.dc:creator: Ken Belson and Mike Isaac
item.media:description: The Super Bowl in Silicon Valley “is tech billionaires who got picked last in gym class paying $50,000 to pretend they’re friends with the guys who got picked first,” a venture capitalist said.

item.title: Fake Post About Racist Video Looked to Be Trump’s on Truth Social
item.description: The post, which spread widely, appeared to describe the president’s rationale for deleting a racist video about the Obamas that he had shared.
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The spread of the fake post appeared to be aided in part by the confusion surrounding how President Trump came to post the original racist video and why it was taken down.

item.title: Prediction Markets and Casinos Go to War Over Sports Betting
item.description: Kalshi and Polymarket say their prediction markets are not subject to gambling laws and taxes. The casino industry is lobbying to shut them down as a wave of court cases take on the question.
item.dc:creator: Ian Frisch
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bettors legally wager more than $220 billion on sports each year.

item.title: Stop Pretending You ‘Need’ Your Phone ‘for Work’
item.description: Plus, summoning the courage to loaf off as flagrantly as the person in the next cubicle.
item.dc:creator: Max Read
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Margeaux Walter for The New York Times

item.title: Binance Gives Trump Family’s Crypto Firm a Leg Up
item.description: Ties between the exchange and the president’s company, World Liberty Financial, have only strengthened since the president pardoned Binance’s founder, Changpeng Zhao.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:description: Binance has offered a series of marketing promotions to encourage its customers to buy World Liberty Financial’s stablecoin.

item.title: Stocks Rebound After Volatile Week as Dow Hits Record High
item.description: The Dow Jones industrial average surpassed 50,000 points for the first time, as old line stocks come back into vogue.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison
item.media:description: The Dow Jones industrial average on Friday had its best day since May as it closed above 50,000 points for the first time.

item.title: Paul Weiss Partners Turned on Brad Karp After Learning Extent of His Epstein Ties
item.description: Mr. Karp resigned as chairman of the elite law firm after senior partners met to decide his future.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Rob Copeland, Maureen Farrell and Matthew Goldstein
item.media:credit: Carly Zavala for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brad Karp’s problems began months ago when embarrassing revelations about his dealings with Jeffrey Epstein began to dribble out of the Justice Department’s files.

item.title: TrumpRx: What to Know About Insurance Benefits, Pricing and Savings
item.description: People may be able to pay less for prescriptions with their insurance rather than via the new government website. The Trump drugstore is meant to help people buy medications using their own money.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: President Trump; Dr. Mehmet Oz, who oversees Medicare and Medicaid; and Joe Gebbia, who oversees the design of government websites, unveiled TrumpRx at the Eisenhower Executive Office Building on Thursday.

item.title: Google Workers Demand End to Cloud Services for Immigration Agencies
item.description: More than 800 employees delivered a petition to management, condemning the Trump administration’s use of Google technology in immigration enforcement.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:description: Federal agents leaving the area where Renee Good was killed in Minneapolis.

item.title: Stellantis’s Shift Away From Electric Cars Will Cost It $26 Billion
item.description: The company, which owns Chrysler, Fiat, Jeep and Peugeot, is changing its strategy to gasoline and hybrid vehicles in an effort to revive weak sales.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:description: Stellantis, which was created after the 2021 merger of Fiat Chrysler and Peugeot, is pulling back from its plans to offer many more electric models.

item.title: A Reprieve for Veterans Applying for V.A. Mortgages
item.description: House Republicans have scaled back a proposal to charge higher fees for the loans after opposition from veterans groups. But it still includes a higher fee for refinancings.
item.dc:creator: Ann Carrns

item.title: A Reprieve for the Markets, but For How Long?
item.description: Technology stocks and Bitcoin are showing signs of a rebound after a disastrous week. But investors remain on edge about whether more pain is in store.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Ian Mount
item.media:credit: Lucia Vazquez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amazon plans to spend heavily on artificial intelligence. Investors seemingly disapprove.

item.title: Europe Accuses TikTok of ‘Addictive Design’ and Pushes for Change
item.description: European Union regulators said the app’s infinite scroll and personalized algorithm led to “compulsive” behavior, especially among children.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: TikTok and other social media companies are under mounting pressure globally for hooking young users.

item.title: Fear of AI Replacing Software Makers Hits Stocks. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: The prospect of disruptions from artificial intelligence has hung over the economy for years. But this week advances in software tools precipitated a sell-off on Wall Street.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac, Joe Rennison and Maureen Farrell

item.title: Nike and Trump’s Supporters Have Been on a Collision Course for Years
item.description: The chair of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has long opposed diversity initiatives like those that Nike embraced.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Davis O’Brien and Kim Bhasin
item.media:credit: Gabby Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nike is under federal investigation over its efforts to increase racial diversity in its employee and leadership ranks.

item.title: ‘Gang Stuff’ and ‘Illicit Trysts’: How Epstein Sought Leverage With the Wealthy
item.description: Jeffrey Epstein drafted letters to men like the retail billionaire Leslie Wexner in which he hinted at shared secrets.
item.dc:creator: Steve Eder, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Matthew Goldstein
item.media:credit: Fred Squillante/Columbus Dispatch, via USA Today Network
item.media:description: Leslie Wexner, the retail billionaire behind Victoria’s Secret, was one of Jeffrey Epstein’s most important clients.

item.title: It’s Time to Rethink the Standard Investment Advice. But Not Too Much.
item.description: With signs of trouble popping up in financial markets, investors need to decide whether they can ignore the turmoil, our columnist says.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Sommer

item.title: The 2026 Super Bowl Ads, Ranked
item.description: Here is our critic’s survey of this year’s Super Bowl commercials, from best to worst to A.I.
item.dc:creator: Mike Hale
item.media:description: George Clooney pitches Grubhub in one of two Super Bowl ads directed by Yorgos Lanthimos.

item.title: 2025 Tax Returns: Here’s What to Know About Filing This Year
item.description: Many Americans will see bigger refunds and new deductions, while others may be revisiting the dreaded alternative minimum tax. Don’t panic just yet.
item.dc:creator: Tara Siegel Bernard and Ron Lieber

item.title: 7 Brothers, a Rom-com and a Dream
item.description: These siblings (and an in-law) turned their childhood love of Hollywood into a family enterprise that has resulted in “Solo Mio,” starring Kevin James.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: The brothers have been making movies together since childhood. From left: Wil, Jeff Azize (actually a brother-in-law), Pete, Dan, Brendan, Chuck, Pat and John.

item.title: Toyota Names Kenta Kon C.E.O. as Automaker Faces Tariffs and Increasing Competition
item.description: The world’s biggest automaker has navigated the industry’s turbulent E.V. transition, but is looking to new leadership to manage intensifying geopolitical challenges.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: Kenta Kon, the next chief executive of Toyota, at a news conference in Tokyo on Friday.

item.title: An Indian Film Embraces a Taj Majal Conspiracy Theory
item.description: The internet and a new film have breathed life into old conspiracy theories about one of the world’s most famous landmarks.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Saumya Khandelwal

item.title: TrumpRx, the President’s Online Drugstore, Opens for Business
item.description: TrumpRx is aimed at helping patients use their own money to buy medicines. But researchers who study drug pricing warned that many patients could pay too much if they use the site.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Margot Sanger-Katz
item.media:description: The TrumpRx website is meant to be an entry point for consumers to search for their medicines and then direct them to manufacturers’ websites to buy the drugs directly.
